A 2005 study found that over 95% of Egyptian women have undergone some form of FGM.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL30168862 "Egypt death sparks debate on female circumcision"], Reuters, 20 June 2007.</ref> In a 2014 UNICEF report, the prevalence had dropped to 91%.<ref name=childinfo/> The 2016 UNICEF report stated that the share of girls aged 15 to 19 who had undergone FGM dropped from 97% in 1985 to 70% in 2015.<ref name=UNICEF2016/> The percentage of girls and women aged 15 to 49 years who had undergone FGM in the years 2004–2015 was 87%, while girls aged 0 to 14 years who had undergone FGM in the years 2010–2015 numbered 14%.<ref name=UNICEF2016/> 38% of girls and women aged 15 to 49 years who had heard about FGM thought the practice should end, while 28% of the boys and men those ages did.<ref name=UNICEF2016/>
===Eritrea===
The government of [[Eritrea]] surveyed and published an official FGM prevalence rate of 89% in 2003.<ref name=dkerit>Diana Kuring(2008) Female Genital Mutilation in Eritrea: Regional Variations" (Chapter 4, pp. 57 – 120) in: Weibliche Genitalverstümmelung in Eritrea. Regionale Er- klärungen, nationale Ansätze und internationale Standards, Saarbrücken: VDM Verlag Dr. Müller, 2008; see summary here: [http://www.ddv-verlag.de/issn_1570_0038_FE%2009_2010.pdf starting page 105]</ref> It was once over 93%. Historically, about 50% of the women in rural areas underwent Type III with stitching to close the vulva, while Type I and II was more common in urban areas. Overall, about a third of all women in Eritrea have undergone Type III FGM with stitching.<ref>[http://www.prb.org/pdf10/fgm-wallchart2010.pdf Female Genital Mutilation/ Cutting: Data and Trends: UPDATE 2010] UNICEF, Page 7</ref><!-- Article would benefit from the addition to the historical data of current data. {{Disputed inline|DYING OUT|for= no longer true. While prevalence remains high, total incidence (once 93%) has been dropping and is closer to 10%. See [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Percentage_of_girls_aged_0_to_14_years_who_have_undergone_FGM_(as_reported_by_their_mothers)_(with_Eritrea_highlighted).png chart 1] and [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Chart_-_Female_Genital_Mutilation_by_country_by_age_range_at_cutting.png chart 2] [http://www.unicef.org/about/annualreport/files/Eritrea_COAR_2013.pdf report 1]|date=September 2016}}--> Most FGM (68%) are performed on baby girls less than 1 year old, another 20% before they turn 5 year old.<ref name=dkerit/> About 60% and 18% of Eritrean women believe FGM is a religious requirement, according to UNICEF, and the Eritrean government, respectively.<ref name="Female Genetic Mutilation/Cutting"/><ref name=dkerit/><sup>p. 109</sup>
The prevalence varies with [[Eritrea#Religion|woman's religion]], as well as by their ethnic group. A 2002 UNICEF study shows FGM prevalence among 99% of Muslim, 89% of Catholic and 85% of Protestant women aged 15–49 years.<ref name=unicefstat2010/> Eritrea outlawed all forms of female genital mutilation with Proclamation 158/2007 in March 2007.<ref name=USStateDep/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6527619.stm "Eritrea bans female circumcision"], BBC News, 4 April 2007.</ref> The law envisions a fine and imprisonment for anyone conducting or commissioning FGM.<ref>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-gesetzgebung-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation and Legislation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003052759/http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-gesetzgebung-2011.pdf |date=2013-10-03 }} Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (January 2011)</ref>
===Ethiopia=== The WHO gives a prevalence of 65% for FGM in [[Ethiopia]] (2016) in women age 15-49 and falling to 47.1 in those 15–19 years. In a 2016 UNICEF report, [[Ethiopia]]'s regional prevalence of FGM is : [[Afar Region]] – 91.2%; [[Somali Region]] – 98.5%; [[Harari Region]] – 81.7%; [[Dire Dawa]] 75.3%; [[Amhara Region]] – 1.4% to 21.9%;<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.2147/IJWH.S28805 | title=Female genital mutilation: prevalence, perceptions and effect on women's health in Kersa district of Ethiopia | year=2012 | journal=International Journal of Women's Health | page=45 | author=Shanko Yirga Wondimu, Kassa Nega, Gebremichael Mengistu, Aro Arja R}}.</ref> [[Oromia Region]] – 75.6%; [[Addis Ababa]] City – 54%; [[Benishangul-Gumuz Region]] – 62.9%; [[Tigray Region]] – 24.2%; [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region|Southern Region]] – 62%; [[Gambela Region]] 33%. By ethnicity, it has a prevalence of 98.5% in [[Somali people|Somali]]; 92.3% [[Hadiya people|Hadiya]]; 98.4% [[Afar people|Afar]] and 23% [[Tigray people|Tigray]]. The prevalence also varies with religion in Ethiopia; FGM is prevalent in 92% of Muslim women<ref name=unicefstat2010/> and with lower prevalence in other religions: 65.8% Protestants, 58.2% Catholics and 55% Traditional Religions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dhsprogram.com/pubs/pdf/PR81/PR81.pdf|title=The DHS Program - Page Not Found|website=dhsprogram.com}}</ref> FGM has been made illegal by the 2004 Penal Code.<ref>Article 565 - Female Circumcision; Article 566 - Infibulation of the Female Genitalia {{cite web|url=http://sgdatabase.unwomen.org/uploads/Ethiopia%20-%20Revised%20Criminal%20Code%202004.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=December 3, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222202126/http://sgdatabase.unwomen.org/uploads/Ethiopia%20-%20Revised%20Criminal%20Code%202004.pdf |archivedate=February 22, 2014 }}</ref>
===Gambia=== [[File:FGM road sign, Bakau, Gambia, 2005.jpg|thumb|250 px|Anti-FGM road sign, Bakau, Gambia, 2005]] Female genital mutilation is prevalent in [[Gambia]].<ref name="fgmnetwork1"/><ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> In a 2013 report, an estimated 76.3% of girls and women have been subjected to FGM/C.<ref name=kapgh>Kaplan et al., [http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2458/13/851 Knowledge, attitudes and practices of female genital mutilation/cutting among health care professionals in The Gambia: a multiethnic study], BMC Public Health 2013, 13:851</ref> A 2006 UNICEF survey found a 78.3% prevalence rate in Gambia.<ref>[http://www.unicef.org/gambia/MICS_III_Main_Report_final_version.pdf The Gambia MICS 2005-2006 Report] UNICEF and Gambia Bureau of Statistics (2007)</ref> The age when FGM is done on Gambian girls ranges from 7 days after birth up to pre-adolescence.<ref>Hernlund Y: Cutting without ritual and ritual without cutting: female circumcision and the Re-ritualization of initiation in The Gambia. In Female “circumcision” in Africa: culture, controversy and change. Edited by Shell-Duncan B, Hernlund Y. London: Rienner publishers; 2000</ref>
Gambia's predominant religion is Islam (90%), and it has many ethnic groups. Prevalence rates of FGM/C vary significantly between the ethnic groups: Sarahule (FGM rate of 98%), Mandinka (97%), Djola (87%), Serer (43%), and Wolof (12%). Urban areas report FGM/C rates of about 56%, whereas in rural areas, rates exceed 90%. A majority of Gambian women who underwent FGM/C claimed they did it primarily because religion mandates it.<ref name=kapgh/>
A 2011 clinical study reports 66% FGMs in Gambia were Type I, 26% were Type II and 8% Type III.<ref>Kaplan et al. (2011), [http://www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1742-4755-8-26.pdf Health consequences of female genital mutilation/cutting in the Gambia, evidence into action] Reproductive Health, 8:26</ref> About a third of all women in Gambia with FGM/C, including Type I, suffered health complications because of the procedure. In 2015, Gambia's president [[Yahya Jammeh]] has banned FGM.<ref name="bbc.com"/> As FGM is less prevalent among younger women according to [[City University London]] in 2015, this suggested a decline in the practice.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015" />
===Ghana=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Ghana]].<ref name="ecoi" /> According to the WHO, its prevalence is 3.8%. In 1989, the head of the government of Ghana, President Rawlings, issued a formal declaration against FGM. Article 39 of Ghana's Constitution also provides in part that traditional practices that are injurious to a person's health and well being are abolished. The Criminal Code was amended in 1994 to outlaw FGM, and the law was strengthened in 2007.<ref name="un.org"/> Ghana ratified the Maputo Protocol in 2007.<ref name=USStateDep/>
===Guinea=== [[Guinea]] has the second highest FGM prevalence rate in the world.<ref name="Female Genetic Mutilation/Cutting"/> In a 2005 survey, 96% of all Guinea women aged between 15 and 49 had been cut.<ref name=fgmgui2011>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-guinea-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Guinea] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003050527/http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-guinea-2011.pdf |date=2013-10-03 }} Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> That is a slight decline in the practice from the 1999 recorded FGM rate of 98.6%. Among the 15- to 19-year-olds the prevalence was 89%, among 20- to 24-year-olds 95%. About 50% of the women in Guinea believe FGM is a religious requirement.<ref name="Female Genetic Mutilation/Cutting"/> Guinea is predominantly a Muslim country, with 90% of the population practicing Islam. The high FGM rates are observed across all religions in Guinea; FGM is prevalent in 99% of Muslim women, 94% of Catholics and Protestants, and 93% of Animist women.<ref name=unicefstat2010/>
FGM is illegal in Guinea under Article 265 of the Penal Code. The law sentences death to the perpetrator if the girl dies within 40 days after the FGM.<ref name=unlaw09>[https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/egm/vaw_legislation_2009/Expert%20Paper%20EGMGPLHP%20_Berhane%20Ras-Work%20revised_.pdf LEGISLATION TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF FEMALE GENITAL MUTILATION (FGM)] Berhane Ras-Work, United Nations (May 21, 2009)</ref> Article 6 of the Guinean Constitution, which outlaws cruel and inhumane treatment, could be interpreted to include these practices, should a case be brought to the Supreme Court. Guinea signed the Maputo Protocol in 2003 but has not ratified it.<ref name=USStateDep/>
Article 305 of Guinea’s penal code also bans FGM, but nobody has yet been sentenced under any of Guinea's FGM-related laws.<ref name=fgmgui2011/> In Guinea, instead of stopping FGM, the trend is towards medicalisation of FGM, where the mutilation is advertised under hygienic conditions by medically trained staff, who see FGM practice an additional source of income. Per the above 2005 survey, 27% of girls were cut by medically trained staff.
===Guinea-Bissau=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Guinea-Bissau]], and have been estimated at a 50% prevalence rate in 2000.<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> A law banning the practice nationwide was adopted by Parliament in June 2011 with 64 votes to 1. At the time, 45% of women aged 15 to 49 years were affected by FGM. According to a survey, 33% of women favoured a continuation of genital cutting, but 50% of the overall population wanted to abandon the practice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/guineabissau_59787.html |title=New law prohibits practice of female genital mutilation in Guinea-Bissau | At a glance: Guinea-Bissau |publisher=UNICEF |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref>
===Kenya=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Kenya]].<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> The 2014 Kenya Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) estimated the national prevalence of FGM to be 21% among women age 15-49, down from 27% in the 2008/09 survey and 32 percent in the 2003 survey.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://dhsprogram.com/pubs/pdf/FR308/FR308.pdf|title=Kenya DHS 2014|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The prevalence of FGM in 2014 varied widely by age, location, ethnic group, and religion. Prevalence of FGM increases with age. It is lowest among women ages 15–19 at 11.4%, and highest among women aged 45–49 at 40.9%. This trend underscores the declining trend in FGM over time.<ref name=":0" />
By region, prevalence is highest in the former provinces of North Eastern (97.5%), Nyanza (32.4%), Rift Valley (26.9%), and Eastern (26.4%), and lower in Central (16.5%), Coast (10.2%), Nairobi (8.0%), and Western (0.8%). It is more common in rural areas (25.9%) than urban (13.8%).<ref name=":0" /> By ethnic group, FGM is most prevalent among women in the Somali (93.6%), Samburu (86.0%), Kisii (84.4%), and Maasai (77.9%) ethnic groups. By religion, it is more prevalent in Muslim women (51.1%) and women listing no religion (32.9%) and less prevalent in Roman Catholic (21.5%) and Protestant or other Christian women (17.9%).<ref name=":0" />
In 2001 Kenya enacted the Children’s Act, under the provisions of which FGM was criminalized when practiced on girls younger than 18.<ref name="fgmken2011">[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-kenia-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Kenya] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> The practice was made illegal nationwide in September 2011.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/society/sarah-boseley-global-health/2011/sep/08/women-africa "FGM: Kenya acts against unkindest cut"], The Guardian, 8 September 2011.</ref>
===Liberia=== Female genital mutilation is prevalent in [[Liberia]].<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> Genital mutilation is a taboo subject in Liberia. It is difficult to get accurate data on FGM prevalence rate. The FGM procedure is mandatory for initiation of women into the secret Liberia and Sierra Leone society called the [[Sande society]], sometimes called Bondo. A 2007 demographic survey asked women if they belonged to Sande society. It was assumed that those who were part of Sande society had undergone FGM. Based on this estimation method, the prevalence of FGM in Liberia has been estimated as 58%.<ref name=fgmlib2011>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-liberia-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Liberia] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> Liberia has consented to international charters such as CEDAW as well as Africa's Maputo Protocol. National legislation explicitly making FGM punishable by law has yet to be passed.<ref name=unlaw09/><ref name=fgmlib2011/> As FGM was less prevalent among younger women in a 2015 study, this suggested a decline in the practice.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015">{{cite book|last1=Alison MacFarlane et al|title=Prevalence of Female Genital Mutilation in England and Wales: National and local estimates|date=July 2015|publisher=[[City University London]]|location=London|isbn=9781900804936|page=10|url=https://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/282388/FGM-statistics-final-report-21-07-15-released-text.pdf|accessdate=10 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121004826/https://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/282388/FGM-statistics-final-report-21-07-15-released-text.pdf|archivedate=21 January 2018}}</ref>
===Libya=== Female genital mutilation is rarely practiced in Libya. Likely to be found in rural areas.<ref name="ecoi"/>
===Malawi=== Female genital mutilation is practiced in Malawi mostly in the following districts of Malawi. Southern Malawi: Mulanje, Thyolo, Mangochi and parts of Machinga and Chiradzuro District. In the Northern part of Malawi: Nkhatabay. This custom is common among the Tonga tribe, Yao tribe and Lomwe tribe. It is a custom which has been there for generation. In some villages it is deeply routed compared to others . Every FGM camp has its own degree of how deep they want to conduct the custom but the motive is the same. It is shrouded in silence. Not even the government authorities can trace the roots because the high powers are given to the local authorities of the village and clan.<ref name="ecoi" />
===Mali=== Female genital mutilation is prevalent in [[Mali]].<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> The WHO gives a prevalence of 85.2% for women aged 15–49 in 2006 in Mali.<ref name="who.int"/> In a 2007 report,<ref name=fgmmali2007/> 92% of all Mali women between the ages of 15 and 49 had been subjected to FGM. The rates of FGM are lower only among the Sonrai (28%), the Tamachek (32%) and the Bozo people (76%). Nearly half are Type I, another half Type II.<ref name=fgmmali2007>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/en/dokumente/en-fgm-countries-mali.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Mali] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (November 2007)</ref> The prevalence varies with religion in Mali; FGM is prevalent in 92% of Muslim women, 76% of Christians.<ref name=unicefstat2010/>
About 64% of the women of Mali believe FGM is a religious requirement.<ref name="Female Genetic Mutilation/Cutting"/> In 2002, Mali created a government program aimed at discouraging FGM (''Ordinance No. 02-053 portant creation du programme national de lutte contre la pratique de l’excision'' [Ordinance creating a National Program to Fight the Practice of Female Genital Mutilation]).<ref>https://www.k4health.org/sites/default/files/pub_bo_GG_appendA.pdf</ref> There is no specific legislation criminalizing FGM.<ref name=unlaw09/><ref name=fgmmali2007/>
===Mauritania=== Female genital mutilation is prevalent in [[Mauritania]].<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> According to 2001 survey, 71% of all women aged between 15 and 49 had undergone FGM. A 2007 demographic cluster study found no change in FGM prevalence rate in Mauritania.<ref name=unlaw09/><ref name=fgmmau2011>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-mauritania-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Mauritania] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003050515/http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-mauritania-2011.pdf |date=2013-10-03 }} Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> Type II FGM is most frequent. About 57% of Mauritania women believe FGM is a religious requirement.<ref name="Female Genetic Mutilation/Cutting"/> Mauritania is 99% Muslim. The FGM prevalence rate varies by ethnic groups: 92% of Soninke women are cut, about 70% of Fulbe and Moorish women, but only 28% of Wolof women have undergone FGM.<ref name=fgmmau2011/> Mauritania has consented to international charters such as CEDAW as well as Africa's Maputo Protocol. Ordonnance n°2005-015 on child protection restricts FGM.<ref>http://www.africanchildforum.org/clr/Legislation%20Per%20Country/Mauritania/mauritania_childjustice_2005_fr.pdf</ref><ref>[https://www.zonta.org/Portals/0/PDFs/UNICEFLegislativeReformAbandonmentFGMCAugust2010.pdf ]{{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref>
===Mozambique=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Mozambique]].<ref name="ecoi"/>
===Niger=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Niger]].<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> In a 2006 survey, about 2% of Niger women had undergone FGM/C.<ref name="Female Genetic Mutilation/Cutting"/> In 1998, Niger reported a 4.5% prevalence rate.<ref>[http://www.glow-boell.de/media/de/txt_rubrik_2/FGM_Statistic_UNICEF_2005.pdf FGM/C - 2005 Statistics] UNICEF, see page 32</ref> This survey data is potentially incorrect because, adjusted for age group, the women who claimed to have experienced FGM at the previous survey still are, albeit in a different age group. The 2006 survey implies more women had never experienced FGM than previously reported. The DHS surveyors claim the adoption of criminal legislation and fear of prosecution may explain why Niger women did not want to report having ever been circumcised.<ref>[http://www.measuredhs.com/pubs/pdf/FR193/FR193-NI06.pdf Enquête Démographique et de Santé et à Indicateurs Multiples 2006] RÉPUBLIQUE DU NIGER; page 281 (in French, use an internet translator if you are not fluent in French)</ref> A WHO report estimates the prevalence rate of FGM in Niger to be 20%.<ref>[https://apps.who.int/dsa/cat98/fgmbook.htm Female Genital Mutilation: An overview] WHO, Geneva</ref> Other sources, including a UNICEF 2009 report, claim FGM rates are high in Niger.<ref>[http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/niger_49292.html Ten villages unite to say 'no’ to female genital mutilation/cutting in Niger] UNICEF (2009)</ref><ref>[http://www.engenderhealth.org/files/pubs/maternal-health/report/section/niger.pdf NIGER] Nathalie Maulet, UNFPA (2007)</ref><ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/printreport.aspx?reportid=48483 NIGER: Legal ban on female circumcision widely ignored] IRIN, UN News Service (2004)</ref> A law banning FGM was passed in 2003 by the Niger government.<ref>[http://www.unicef.org/wcaro/WCARO_Niger_Factsheet-11.pdf PRIORITIES IN CHILD SURVIVAL, EDUCATION AND PROTECTION - Niger] UNICEF (2007)</ref>
===Nigeria=== {{Main|Female genital mutilation in Nigeria}} A 2008 demographic survey found 30% of all [[Nigeria]]n women have been subjected to FGM.<ref name="fgmnigeria2011">[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-nigeria-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Nigeria] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> This contrasts with 25% reported by a 1999 survey, and 19% by 2003 survey. This suggests no trend, unreliable past or most recent survey data in some regions, as well as the possibility that a number of women are increasingly willing to acknowledge having undergone FGM. Another possible explanation for higher 2008 prevalence rate is the definition of FGM used, which included Type IV FGMs. In some parts of Nigeria, the vagina walls are cut in new born girls or other traditional practices performed - such as the ''angurya'' and ''gishiri'' cuts - which fall under Type IV FGM classification of the World Health Organization.<ref name="fgmnigeria2011" /> Over 80% of all FGMs are performed on girls under one year of age. The prevalence varies with religion in Nigeria; FGM is prevalent in 31% of Catholics, 27% of Protestant and 7% of Muslim women.<ref name="unicefstat2010" /> FGM was banned throughout the country in 2015.<ref name="theguardian1" /><ref name="reuters1" />
===Republic of the Congo=== Female genital mutilation is practiced in the [[Republic of the Congo]],<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> and has been estimated at a 5% prevalence rate.<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/>
===Senegal=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Senegal]].<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> According to 2005 survey, FGM prevalence rate is 28% of all women aged between 15 and 49.<ref name=fgmsen2011>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-senegal-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Senegal] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> There are significant differences in regional prevalence. FGM is most widespread in the Southern Senegal (94% in Kolda Region) and in Northeastern Senegal (93% in Matam Region). FGM rates are lower in other regions: Tambacounda (86%), Ziguinchor (69%), and less than 5% in Diourbel and Louga Regions. Senegal is 94% Muslim. The FGM prevalence rate varies by religion: 29% of Muslim women have undergone FGM, 16% of Animists, and 11% of Christian women.<ref name=unicefstat2010/><ref name=fgmsen2011/>
A law that was passed in January 1999 makes FGM illegal in Senegal.<ref>[http://2001-2009.state.gov/g/wi/rls/rep/crfgm/10107.htm "Senegal: Report on Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) or Female Genital Cutting (FGC)"], Released by the Office of the Senior Coordinator for International Women's Issues, US Department of State.</ref> President Diouf had appealed for an end to this practice and for legislation outlawing it. The law modifies the Penal Code to make this practice a criminal act, punishable by a sentence of one to five years in prison. A spokesperson for the human rights group RADDHO (The African Assembly for the Defense of Human Rights) noted in the local press that "Adopting the law is not the end, as it will still need to be effectively enforced for women to benefit from it. Senegal ratified the Maputo Protocol in 2005.<ref name=USStateDep/>
===Sierra Leone=== Female genital mutilation is prevalent in [[Sierra Leone]].<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> According to a 2008 survey, 91% of women in Sierra Leone between the ages of 15 and 49 have undergone FGM. The highest rate of prevalence is in the Northern Sierra Leone (97%).<ref name=fgmsile2011>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-sierraleone-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Sierra Leone] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> Type II is most common, but Type I is known as well as Type III. In a 2013 report, researchers first conducted verbal surveys followed by clinical examination. They found that the verbal disclosure were not completely reliable, and clinical examination showed greater extent of FGM. These researchers report 68% Type II and 32% Type I in Sierra Leone women.<ref name="b2013"/>
Like Liberia, Sierra Leone has the traditional secret society of women, called Bondo or [[Sande society]], which uses FGM as part of the initiation rite. 70% of the population is Muslim, 20% Christian, and 10% as traditional religions.<ref name=fgmsile2011/> Only Creole Christians of Sierra Leone are known to not practice FGM. There is no federal law against FGM in Sierra Leone; and the ''Soweis'' - those who do FGM excision - wield considerable political power during elections.<ref name=unlaw09/>
===Somalia=== According to a 2005 WHO estimate, about 97.9% of [[Somalia]]'s women and girls underwent FGM. This was at the time the world's highest prevalence rate of the procedure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/topics/fgm/prevalence/en/index.html |title=Prevalence of FGM |publisher=Who.int |date=2010-12-09 |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> A 2010 UNICEF report also noted that Somalia had the world's highest rate of Type III FGM, with 79% of all Somali women having undergone the procedure; another 15% underwent Type II FGM.<ref name="prb.org"/> The prevalence rate varies considerably by region and is on the decline in the northern part of the country. In 2013, UNICEF in conjunction with the Somali authorities reported that the FGM prevalence rate among 1- to 14-year-old girls in the autonomous northern [[Puntland]] and [[Somaliland]] regions had dropped to 25% following a social and religious awareness campaign.<ref name="Jpsfgmd">{{cite news|title=Somalia: Female genital mutilation down|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/04/16/somalia-female-genital-mutilation-down.html|accessdate=17 May 2013|newspaper=Associated Press via The Jakarta Post|date=16 April 2013}}</ref> Article 15 of the [[Constitution of Somalia|Federal Constitution]] adopted in August 2012 also prohibits female circumcision.<ref name="Frspc">{{cite web|title=The Federal Republic of Somalia - Provisional Constitution |url=http://www.somaliweyn.com/pages/news/Aug_12/Somalia_Constitution_English_FOR_WEB.pdf |accessdate=13 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228121925/http://www.somaliweyn.com/pages/news/Aug_12/Somalia_Constitution_English_FOR_WEB.pdf |archivedate=28 December 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===South Africa=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[South Africa]].<ref name="ecoi" />
===South Sudan=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[South Sudan]], but its exact prevalence is unknown. A 2015 UNICEF report claimed 1% of women aged 15–49 had been subjected to FGM, but as of May 2018 there were no recent data confirming this figure. FGM has been reported to be practiced in some Christian and Muslims communities, and has been noted in some refugee camps in [[Upper Nile State]]. South Sudanese law has banned female genital mutilation, but the government has not enacted a clear plan to eradicate the phenomenon.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.28toomany.org/static/media/uploads/Law%20Reports/south_sudan_law_report_v1_(may_2018).pdf |title=South Sudan: the law and FGM |author= |work=28 Too Many 2018 |publisher=Thomas Reuters Foundation |date=May 2018 |accessdate=29 June 2018}}</ref>
===Sudan=== The prevalence of FGM in Sudan is 90%.<ref name="applications.emro.who.int">http://applications.emro.who.int/docs/High_Level_Exp_Meet_Rep_2013_EN_14808.pdf</ref> Only some [[states of Sudan]] have laws against FGM;<ref>http://www.prb.org/pdf14/progress-ending-fgm.pdf</ref> currently there is no national law forbidding FGM, although Sudan was the first country to outlaw it in 1946, under the British. Type III was prohibited under the 1925 Penal Code, with less severe forms allowed. Outreach groups have been trying to eradicate the practice for 50 years, working with NGOs, religious groups, the government, the media and medical practitioners. Arrests have been made but no further action seems to have taken place.<ref name=USStateDep/> Sudan signed the Maputo Protocol in June, 2008 but no ratification has yet been deposited with the African Union.
===Tanzania=== According to 2015-16 survey in [[Tanzania]],<ref name="ReferenceB"/> FGM prevalence rate is 10% of all women aged between 15 and 49 and 4.7% for those aged 15–19. In contrast, the 1996 survey reported 17.6, suggesting a drop of 7.6% over 20 years or unwillingness to disclose. Type II FGM was found to be most common. There are significant differences in regional prevalence; FGM is most widespread in Manyara (81%), Dodoma (68%), Arusha (55%), Singida (43%) and Mara (38%) regions.<ref name=fgmtanz2011>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-tansania-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Tanzania] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> The practice varies with religion, with reported prevalence rates of 20% for Christian and 15% of Muslim women.<ref name=unicefstat2010/>
Section 169A of the Sexual Offences Special Provisions Act of 1998 prohibits FGM in Tanzania. Punishment is imprisonment of from five to fifteen years or a fine not exceeding 300,000 shillings (approximately US$250) or both. Tanzania ratified the Maputo Protocol in 2007. As with Kenya, Tanzania 1998 Act protects only girls up to the age of 18 years. The FGM law is being occasionally implemented, with 52 violations have been reported, filed and prosecuted. At least 10 cases were convicted in Tanzania.<ref name=unlaw09/>
===Togo=== Female genital mutilation is practiced in [[Togo]]. In a 2014 UNICEF report, the prevalence is 1.8% in girls 15-19.<ref name="unfpa.org"/> The WHO puts its prevalence at 5.8% in 2006.<ref name="who.int"/> Other sources cite 12%<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and 50%<ref name="brighamandwomens1"/> as prevalence. Type II is usually practiced.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> On October 30, 1998, the National Assembly unanimously voted to outlaw the practice of FGM. Penalties under the law can include a prison term of two months to ten years and a fine of 100,000 francs to one million francs (approximately US$160 to 1,600). A person who had knowledge that the procedure was going to take place and failed to inform public authorities can be punished with one month to one year imprisonment or a fine of from 20,000 to 500,000 francs (approximately US$32 to 800). Togo ratified the Maputo Protocol in 2005.<ref name=USStateDep/>
===Uganda=== [[File:Campaign road sign against female genital mutilation (cropped) 2.jpg|thumb|250px|Road sign near [[Kapchorwa]], [[Uganda]], 2004]] Anyone convicted of carrying out FGM is subject to 10 years in prison. If the life of the patient is lost during the operation a life sentence is recommended.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8406940.stm "Uganda Bans Female Genital Mutilation"], BBC News, |10 December 2009.</ref> In 1996, a court intervened to prevent the performance of FGM under Section 8 of the Children Statute, which makes it unlawful to subject a child to social or customary practices harmful to the child's health. Uganda signed the Maputo Protocol in 2003 but has not ratified it.<ref>[http://www.ugpulse.com/articles/daily/news.asp?about=Uganda%20asked%20to%20ratify%20Women’s%20rights%20protocol&ID=7249 Uganda Government News: Uganda asked to ratify Women’s rights protocol], ''UGPulse'', November 27, 2008</ref> In early July 2009, President Yoweri Museveni stated that a law would soon be passed prohibiting the practice, with alternative livelihoods found for its practitioners.<ref name="Kampala_2007_07_02">[http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/686709 "Museveni condemns genital cutting"], ''The New Vision'', Kampala, 2 July 2007.</ref> The anti FGM act 2010 is currently available for reference.
===Zimbabwe=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Zimbabwe]].<ref name="ecoi" />
==Europe== In recent years the increase in immigration for individuals from countries which practice [[FGM]], has led to the introduction of FGM in European and North American societies. FGM prevalence rate has been difficult to quantify among immigrants to European countries.<ref name=Leye2006>{{Cite journal | last1= Leye | first1= Els | last2= Powell | first2= Richard A. | last3= Nienhuis | first3= Gerda | last4= Claeys | first4= Patricia | last5= Temmerman | first5= Marleen | title = Health care in Europe for women with genital mutilation | journal = [[Health Care for Women International]] | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 362–378 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/07399330500511717 | date = March 2006 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/07399330500511717 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> A case study which investigated FGM in groups of migrant women from [[Northern Africa]] to European regions like Scandinavia, noted that a majority of these women had FGM before their migration to Europe.<ref name=Elgaali2005>{{cite journal|last1=Elgaali|first1=Mahoud | last2= Strevens | first2= Helena | last3= Mårdh | first3= Per-Anders |title= Female genital mutilation – an exported medical hazard |journal= [[The European Journal of Contraception & Reproductive Health Care]] |year=2005|volume=10 | issue =2|pages=93–97 | publisher = [[Informa]] | doi = 10.1080/13625180400020945 |pmid = 16147813}}</ref>
It has also been established that African communities in European countries continue the practice of FGM on their daughters after migrating to Europe. For instance in [[Sweden]], a study by [[Karolinska Institutet]] concluded that about a third of families migrated from countries with a FGM culture wanted to continue mutilating in their new countries.<ref name=dn_2014-06-24>{{cite news|title=En av tre familjer vill fortsätta omskära|url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/varlden/en-av-tre-familjer-vill-fortsatta-omskara/|accessdate=25 June 2014|publisher=[[Dagens Nyheter]]|date=24 June 2014 }}</ref> The [[Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence]], which came into force on 1 August 2014, defines and criminalize the practice in Article 38:<ref>{{cite web | title = 13 Countries sign new Convention in Istanbul | url = http://www.unric.org/en/violence-against-women/27000-13-countries-sign-new-convention-in-istanbul | website = unric.org | publisher = [[UNRIC|United Nations Regional Information Centre (UNRIC)]] | accessdate = 28 May 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence | url = http://www.conventions.coe.int/Treaty/EN/Treaties/Html/210.htm | website = conventions.coe.int | publisher = [[Council of Europe]] | date = 2011 | accessdate = 28 May 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence (treaty signatures) | url = http://www.conventions.coe.int/Treaty/Commun/ChercheSig.asp?NT=210&CM=&DF=&CL=ENG | website = conventions.coe.int | publisher = [[Council of Europe]] | date = May 2011 | accessdate = 28 May 2015 }}</ref> {{Quotation|Article 38 – Female genital mutilation Parties shall take the necessary legislative or other measures to ensure that the following intentional conducts are criminalised: {{ordered list|type=lower-latin | excising, infibulating or performing any other mutilation to the whole or any part of a woman’s labia majora, labia minora or clitoris; | coercing or procuring a woman to undergo any of the acts listed in point a; | inciting, coercing or procuring a girl to undergo any of the acts listed in point a. }}}}
===France=== Between 1979 and 2004, a total of 29 FGM court cases were brought before criminal courts, mostly from the mid-1990s onwards and with aggravated sentences.<ref>{{cite book |date= 2013 |title= Current situation of female genital mutilation in France |url= http://bookshop.europa.eu/en/current-situation-of-female-genital-mutilation-in-france-pbMH3213138/ |location= Vilnius, Lithuania |publisher= [[European Institute for Gender Equality]] |isbn= 9789292182489 }} [http://eige.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Current%20situation%20and%20trends%20of%20female%20genital%20mutilation%20in%20France_EN.pdf Pdf]</ref> By 2013, more than 100 people had been convicted of FGM.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Joan|title=Convictions for female genital mutilation. France-100 UK-Nil|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/convictions-for-female-genital-mutilation-france-100-uk-nil-8722934.html|publisher=The Independent Newspaper|accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref> FGM is a criminal offense punishable by 10 years or up to 20 years in jail if the victim is under 15 years of age.<ref name=guardian_10February2014/> The law requires anyone to report any case of mutilation or planned mutilation. In 2014 it was reported that about 100 people in France had been jailed.<ref name=guardian_10February2014/> Not only the person carrying out the mutilation is sentenced, parents organising the crime face legal proceedings as well.<ref name=guardian_10February2014>{{cite news|last1=Wilsher|first1=Kim|title=France's tough stance on female genital mutilation is working, say campaigners|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/feb/10/france-tough-stance-female-genital-mutilation-fgm|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=10 February 2014}}</ref>
===Germany=== According to women's right organisation [[Terre des Femmes]] in 2014, there were 25,000 victims in [[Germany]] and a further 2,500 are under threat of becoming mutilated.<ref name=diewelt_06.02.14>{{cite news|last1=Réthy|first1=Laura|title=Wo beschnittene Frauen ihre Würde zurückerlangen|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article124568990/Wo-beschnittene-Frauen-ihre-Wuerde-zurueckerlangen.html|accessdate=25 June 2014|work=[[Die Welt]]|publisher=[[Axel Springer AG]]|date=6 February 2014}}</ref> In 2018, the estimate had increased to {{Val|65000}}. A further {{Val|15500}} were at risk of having the mutilation done to them which represented an increase of 17% on the previous year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.welt.de/newsticker/news2/article179875242/Frauen-In-Deutschland-65-000-Frauen-und-Maedchen-von-Genitalverstuemmelung-betroffen.html|title=Frauen: In Deutschland 65.000 Frauen und Mädchen von Genitalverstümmelung betroffen|last=WELT|date=2018-07-24|work=DIE WELT|access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref>
===Italy=== After a few cases of infibulation practiced by complaisant medical practitioners within the African immigrant community came to public knowledge through media coverage, the Law n°7/2006 was passed on 1/9/2006, becoming effective on 1/28/2006, concerning "Measures of prevention and prohibition of any female genital mutilation practice"; the Act is also known as the ''Legge Consolo'' ("Consolo Act") named after its primary promoter, Senator Giuseppe Consolo. Article 6 of the law integrates the Italian Penal Code with Articles 583-''Bis'' and 583-''Ter'', punishing any practice of female genital mutilation "not justifiable under therapeutical or medical needs" with imprisonment ranging from 4 to 12 years (3 to 7 years for any mutilation other than, or less severe than, clitoridectomy, excision or infibulation).<ref>[http://www.parlamento.it/leggi/06007l.htm Italian Law n°7 1/9/2006, ''Disposizioni concernenti la prevenzione e il divieto delle pratiche di mutilazione genitale femminile''], accessed 23 March 2009.</ref>
The penalty can be reduced up to {{frac|2|3}} if the harm caused is of modest entity (i.e. if partially or completely unsuccessful), but may also be elevated up to {{frac|3}} if the victim is a minor or if the offense has been committed for profit. An Italian citizen or a foreign citizen legally resident in Italy can be punished under this law even if the offense is committed abroad; the law will as well afflict any individual of any citizenship in Italy, even illegally or provisionally. The law also mandates any medical practitioner found guilty under those provisions to have his/her medical license revoked for a minimum of six up to a maximum of ten years.<ref>[http://www.parlamento.it/leggi/06007l.htm Italian Law n°7 1/9/2006, ''Disposizioni concernenti la prevenzione e il divieto delle pratiche di mutilazione genitale femminile''], accessed 23 March 2009.</ref>
===Netherlands=== FGM is considered mutilation and is punishable as a criminal offense under Dutch law. There is no specific law against FGM: the act is subsumed under the general offense of inflicting harm (''"mishandeling"'' in Dutch, art. 300–304 Dutch Criminal Code). The maximum penalty is a prison sentence of 12 years. The sentence can be higher if the offender is a family member of the victim. It is also illegal to assist or encourage another person to perform FGM. A Dutch citizen or a foreign citizen legally resident in the Netherlands can be punished even if the offense is committed abroad. Doctors have the obligation to report suspected cases of FGM and may break patient confidentiality rules if necessary.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}}
===Norway=== FGM is punishable as a criminal offense under Norwegian law even if the offense is committed abroad.<ref>{{cite web | title = Laws of the world on female genital mutilation | url = http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/population/fgm/fgm.htm | website = hsph.harvard.edu | publisher = [[Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health]] | date = 2 February 2010 | accessdate = 28 May 2015 }}</ref>
===Russia=== A study on female genital mutilation practiced in [[Dagestan]], made public in 2016 by Legal Initiative for Russia, revealed that FGM is widespread in [[Dagestan]]. The girls undergo mutilation in early age, up to three years old. The practice has been publicly approved in the predominantly [[Muslim]] region of [[Dagestan]] by religious leaders such as [[Mufti]] [[Ismail Berdiyev]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Outrage in Russia after religious leaders back female genital mutilation | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/18/outrage-in-russia-after-religious-leaders-back-female-genital-mu/ | publisher = The Telegraph | date = 16 August 2016 | accessdate = 25 August 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Female mutilation in the Caucasus | url = http://jam-news.net/Publication/Get/en-US/1953 | publisher = JAMnews | date = 22 August 2016 | accessdate = 25 August 2016 }}</ref> Later an Orthodox Christian priest also backed the cleric.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37115746|title=Russia furore over FGM in mainly Muslim Dagestan|date=18 August 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
===Spain=== The Criminal Code does state that sexual mutilation, such as FGM, is a criminal offense punishable by up to 12 years in jail, even if the offence is committed abroad.
===Sweden=== In 1982, [[Sweden]] was the first western country in the world to explicitly prohibit genital mutilation.<ref name="FGM-Sweden">{{cite web|author1=Richard Orange|author2=Alexandra Topping|title=FGM specialist calls for gynaecological checks for all girls in Sweden|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/jun/27/female-genital-mutilation-fgm-specialist-sweden-gynaecological-checks-children|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 October 2014|date=27 June 2014|quote=The pilot in Norrköping, which grabbed headlines when it was wrongly reported that an entire school class of girls had been subjected to FGM, 28 in the most severe fashion [...] Sweden was the first country in the world to ban FGM in 1982, and in 1999 the ban was extended to include circumcision carried out in other countries.}}</ref><ref name="LU-journal">{{Cite book |last=Johnsdotter |first=Sara |title=FGM in Sweden: Swedish legislation regarding "female genital mutilation" and implementation of the law |publisher=[[Lund University]] |location=Sweden |year=2004 |url=http://www.lunduniversity.lu.se/lup/publication/528291 }} Research Report in Sociology 2004:1 [http://www.intact-network.net/intact/cp/files/1385899333_FGM%20in%20Sweden.pdf Pdf] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528073931/http://www.intact-network.net/intact/cp/files/1385899333_FGM%20in%20Sweden.pdf# |date=2015-05-28 }}</ref> It is punishable by up to ten years in prison, and in 1999 the Government extended the law to include procedures performed abroad.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lag (1982:316) med förbud mot könsstympning av kvinnor|url=http://www.riksdagen.se/sv/Dokument-Lagar/Lagar/Svenskforfattningssamling/Lag-1982316-med-forbud-mot-_sfs-1982-316/|publisher=The [[Riksdag]]|accessdate=17 October 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref> General child protection laws could also be used.<ref name="EIGE-Sweden">{{cite web|title=Current situation of female genital mutilation in Sweden|url=http://eige.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Current%20situation%20and%20trends%20of%20female%20genital%20mutilation%20in%20Sweden_EN.pdf|publisher=[[European Institute for Gender Equality]]|accessdate=3 January 2015}}</ref> The prevalence of FGM among immigrant groups in Sweden is unknown, but there have been 46 cases of suspected genital mutilation since the law was introduced in 1982, and two convictions, according to a report published in 2011 by the [[National Centre for Knowledge on Men's Violence against Women]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ny rapport om kvinnlig omskärelse/könsstympning|url=http://www.nck.uu.se/NCK_press/Pressmeddelanden/pressmeddelanden-2011/Ny_rapport_om_kvinnlig_omskarelse_konsstympning/|publisher=[[National Centre for Knowledge on Men's Violence against Women]]|accessdate=17 October 2014|language=Swedish|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102120532/http://www.nck.uu.se/NCK_press/Pressmeddelanden/pressmeddelanden-2011/Ny_rapport_om_kvinnlig_omskarelse_konsstympning/#|archive-date=2014-11-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In June 2014, [[Norrköpings Tidningar]] published a story on genital mutilation,<ref>{{cite web|title=Alla 30 flickor i klassen var könsstympade|url=http://nt.se/nyheter/norrkoping/allt-fler-konsstympade-flickor-upptacks-9908656.aspx|publisher=[[Norrköpings Tidningar]]|accessdate=17 October 2014|date=20 June 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref> which was picked up by the foreign press, including [[The Independent]] and [[Daily News (New York)|The Daily News]]. It was claimed that every single girl in one school class had been victims of genital mutilation.<ref>{{cite news|title=FGM in Sweden: School where every single girl in one class underwent procedure exposed|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/fgm-in-sweden-school-where-every-single-girl-in-one-class-underwent-procedure-exposed-9552854.html|publisher=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=17 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Swedish health authorities discover every girl in one class had undergone genital mutilation: report|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/girl-swedish-school-class-underwent-genital-mutilation-report-article-1.1838078|publisher=[[Daily News (New York)|The Daily News]]|accessdate=17 October 2014}}</ref> None of the newspapers said where and when the genital mutilation took place.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nyheten som var en nyhet|url=http://www.nt.se/opinion/debatt/nyheten-som-var-en-nyhet-9943778.aspx|publisher=[[Norrköpings Tidningar]]|accessdate=17 October 2014|language=Swedish|quote=Vi skrev inte om var och när könsstympningen genomförts.}}</ref> It was later published by [[Sveriges Radio|Sweden's national public radio]] that none of the girls had been subjected to the procedure, or had any procedure performed on them abroad, while living in Sweden.<ref name="FGM-Sweden" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Stympad rapportering om könsstympning och nya medievanor|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/avsnitt/388870?programid=2795&playepisode=388870|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]]|accessdate=17 October 2014|language=Swedish|date=28 June 2014}}</ref>
The [[National Board of Health and Welfare]] has estimated that up to 38,000 women living in Sweden may have been the victims of FGM. This calculation is based on [[UNICEF]] estimates on prevalence rates in Africa, and refer to FGM carried out before arriving in Sweden.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Forslind|first1=Elisabet|title=38 000 kvinnor och flickor i Sverige kan vara könsstympade|url=https://www.vardforbundet.se/Vardfokus/Webbnyheter/2015/Januari/38-000-kvinnor-och-flickor-i-Sverige-kan-vara-omskurna/|publisher=[[Swedish Association of Health Professionals]]|accessdate=16 January 2015|language=Swedish|date=2015-01-15}}</ref> In 2014, a Somali-born national coordinator at the [[County Administrative Boards of Sweden|County Administrative Board of Östergötland]] said the problem is not actively being pursued by authorities and the issue is avoided for fear of being perceived as racist or as stigmatising minority ethnic groups.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nilsson|first1=Hedvig|title=Tusentals könsstympade barn lider i det tysta|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=93&artikel=5994440|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]]|accessdate=16 January 2015|language=Swedish}}</ref> The [[Ministry of Health and Social Affairs (Sweden)|Ministry of Health and Social Affairs]] launched an action plan against FGM in 2003, which included giving courses to African women and men, who are now working as health advisors and influencing the public opinion among their fellow countrymen.<ref name="LU-journal" /> The Government have also issued guidelines for officials in the social sector concerning actions and measures in a variety of situations.<ref name="EIGE-Sweden" />
===United Kingdom=== {{main|Female genital mutilation in the United Kingdom}} FGM was made a criminal offence by the [[Prohibition of Female Circumcision Act 1985]].<ref name=Kerjab>Kerbaj, Richard. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/health/article5913979.ece "Thousands of girls mutilated in Britain"], ''The Times'', 16 March 2009.</ref> This was superseded by the [[Female Genital Mutilation Act 2003]], and (in Scotland) by the [[Prohibition of Female Genital Mutilation (Scotland) Act 2005]]. Taking a UK citizen or permanent resident abroad for the purpose of FGM is a criminal offence whether or not it is lawful in the country the girl is taken to.<ref>{{cite web | title = Notes on some overseas countries' laws | url = http://www.fgmnetwork.org/legisl/interntl/overseas.php | website = fgmnetwork.org | publisher = The Female Genital Cutting Education and Networking Project | accessdate = 28 May 2015 }}</ref> Since April 2014, all NHS hospitals will be able to record if a patient has undergone FGM or if there is a family history of this, and by September 2014, all acute hospitals will have to report this data to the Department of Health, on a monthly basis.<ref>{{cite news|title=Female genital mutilation: Hospitals to log victims |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-26049733 |accessdate= 28 May 2015|work=News|publisher=BBC News|date= 6 February 2014 }}</ref> Despite FGM being illegal since 1985 the authorities are yet to prosecute even one case successfully.{{specify|have there been trials with no convictions? How many?|date=January 2018}}
The number of women aged 15–49 resident in England and Wales born in FGM practising regions having migrated to the UK was {{val|182000}} in 2001 and increased to {{val|283000}} in 2011.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015_p5" /> The number of women born in the [[Horn of Africa]], where FGM is nearly universal and the most severe types of FGM, infubulation, is commonly practised, increased from {{val|22000}} in 2001 to {{val|56000}} in 2011, an increase of {{val|34000}}.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015_p5">{{cite book|last1=Alison MacFarlane et al|title=Prevalence of Female Genital Mutilation in England and Wales: National and local estimates|date=July 2015|publisher=[[City University London]]|location=London|isbn=9781900804936|page=5|url=https://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/282388/FGM-statistics-final-report-21-07-15-released-text.pdf|accessdate=10 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121004826/https://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/282388/FGM-statistics-final-report-21-07-15-released-text.pdf|archivedate=21 January 2018}}</ref>
The number of women of all ages having undergone FGM rituals was estimated to be {{val|137000}} in 2011.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015_p5"/> The number of women of ages 15–49 having undergone FGM rituals was estimated to {{val|66000}} in 2001 and there was an increase to {{val|103000}} in 2011.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015_p5"/> Additionally, approximately 10,000 girls aged under 15 and 24,000 women over 50, who have migrated to England and Wales, are likely to have undergone FGM.<ref>{{cite web | title = New research: 137,000 women and girls in England and Wales affected by FGM | url = http://www.equalitynow.org/sites/default/files/Prevalence_of_FGM_in_England_and_Wales.pdf | accessdate = 5 January 2016 }}</ref>
The city with the highest prevalence of FGM in 2015 was [[London]], at a rate of 28.2 per 1000 women aged 15–49, by far the highest.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015_p21">{{cite book|last1=Alison MacFarlane et al|title=Prevalence of Female Genital Mutilation in England and Wales: National and local estimates|date=July 2015|publisher=[[City University London]]|location=London|isbn=9781900804936|page=21|url=https://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/282388/FGM-statistics-final-report-21-07-15-released-text.pdf|accessdate=10 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121004826/https://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/282388/FGM-statistics-final-report-21-07-15-released-text.pdf|archivedate=21 January 2018}}</ref> The borough with the highest rate was [[Southwark]], at 57.5 per 1000 women, while mainly rural areas of the UK had prevalence rate below 1 per 1000.<ref name="CUL_Prevalence_FGM_Jul2015_p21" />
==Middle East== ===Bahrain=== {{Expand section|date=November 2014}} Female genital mutilation is present in [[Bahrain]].<ref name="irinnews.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/InDepthMain.aspx?InDepthId=15&ReportId=62465 |title=IRIN | In-Depth: Razor's Edge - The Controversy of Female Genital Mutilation | AFRICA: FGM and the power of tradition | AFRICA | Children | Conflict | Gender Issues |publisher=Irinnews.org |date=2005-03-01 |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>Gilbert, D. (1993). For the sake of purity (and control). Female genital mutilation. Links (New York, NY), 9(5), 6</ref>
=== Iran === National data on FGM in Iran are unknown. Various studies have been conducted on prevalence in provinces and counties, suggesting significant regional differences.<ref name="OrchidIran">{{Cite web |url=http://orchidproject.org/country/iran/ |title=Iran |publisher=[[Orchid Project]] |accessdate=4 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://kameelahmady.com/wp-content/uploads/Kameel%20-%20EN%20Final.pdf |title=A comprehensive research study on female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) in Iran |author=Kameel Ahmady |publisher=Kameel Ahmady |date=2015 |accessdate=5 August 2018}}</ref> FGM is known to be prevalent in four provinces: [[West Azerbaijan Province]] (mostly the Kurdish populated southern part), [[Kurdistan Province]] and [[Kermanshah Province]] in the Kurdish-dominated northwest, and [[Hormozgan Province]] and islands near it in the south.<ref name="Ahmady20">Ahmady (2015), p. 20.</ref>
FGM in Iran is primarily associated with Sunni Muslims following the [[Shafi‘i]] [[madhhab]], especially those living in certain Kurdish-populated rural areas in northwestern Iran, adjacent to the Kurdish-speaking regions in northeastern Iraq where FGM also has a relatively high presence compared to the non-Kurdish areas around it. There is strong disparity even within the Kurdish communities, and the prevalence may differ considerably from one village to the next.<ref name="Ahmady14">Ahmady (2015), p. 14.</ref> Unlike the [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] government, which has implemented a relatively successful anti-FGM campaign, official representatives as well as nationalist individuals or groups tend to deny FGM even exists in Iran.<ref name="Ahmady14"/> In the southern province of Hormozgan, FGM is mostly practiced by (Persian) Sunnis, but also a small minority of Shias living near them.<ref name="Ahmady20"/>
The issue is rarely discussed in public; the national Shia religious establishment claims it as an exclusively Sunni practice in which it should not get involved, and generally sees no reason to try and end it. It is also rarely the subject of research in academia, with the government neither permitting nor funding any public engagement projects for the affected regions.<ref name="Ahmady15">Ahmady (2015), p. 15.</ref>
In 2016, Susie Latham reported that FGC had been abandoned around the capital of the south-western province Khuzestan in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/17496535.2016.1167227 | volume=10 | issue=2 | title=The campaign against Female Genital Cutting: empowering women or reinforcing global inequity? | year=2016 | journal=Ethics and Social Welfare | pages=108–121 | author=Latham Susie}}</ref> Research by Kameel Ahmady (2005–2015) also revealed the practice had been abandoned in several other parts of Iran, such as among Shia Kurdish women in parts of Kermanshah and [[Ilam Province]].<ref name="Ahmady20"/>
Some studies estimate the Type I and II FGM among Iraqi migrants and other Kurdish minority groups to be variable, ranging from 40% to 85%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stopfgmmideast.org/countries/iran/ |title=» Iran |publisher=Stopfgmmideast.org |date= |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>Golnaz Esfandiari (2009-03-10). "Female Genital Mutilation Said To Be Widespread In Iraq's, Iran's Kurdistan". Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty</ref><ref>Saleem, R. A., Othman, N., Fattah, F. H., Hazim, L., & Adnan, B. (2013). Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan: description and associated factors. Women & health, 53(6), 537-551</ref> [[File:Prevalence of FGM Iran by province in 2014.svg|300px|thumb|2014 prevalence of female genital mutilation in Iran by province.<ref name="Ahmady27"/> {{Legend|#FF2500|50–70%}} {{Legend|#FF9900|15–30%}} {{Legend|#FEFEE4|No data; presumably below 1%}}]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ FGM in Iran by province<ref name="Ahmady27">Ahmady (2015), p. 27.</ref> |- ! Province !! 2009 !! 2010 !! 2011 !! 2012 !! 2013 !! 2014 |- | [[Hormozgan Province]] || – || – || 68% || 66% || 62% || 60% |- | [[Kermanshah Province]] || – || 31% || 28% || 25% || 20% || 18% |- | [[Kurdistan Province]] || – || 29% || 28% || 23% || 20% || 16% |- | [[West Azerbaijan Province]] || 39% || 36% || 32% || 32% || 25% || 21% |- |} Assuming FGM had no significant presence in other provinces, this would amount to a national prevalence of c. 2% in Iran in 2014.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |+ FGM in Iran by county |- ! County !! Prevalence !! Notes !! Source |- | [[Ravansar County]] || 55.7% || || Tahereh Pashaei et al.<ref name="OrchidIran"/> |- | [[Minab County]] || 70% || || Khadivzadeh et al.<ref name="OrchidIran"/> |- | [[Qeshm County]] || 7.2% (Shia Muslims)<br />70% (Sunni Muslims) || FGM in decline || <ref name="OrchidIran"/> |}
===Iraq=== [[File:FGM prevalence UNICEF 2013 Iraq.png|thumb|upright=1.35|alt=map|Prevalence of FGM in Iraq for women aged 15–49 using UNICEF "Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting, 2013, from [http://www.unicef.org/media/files/FGCM_Lo_res.pdf]. More recent 2016 survey: [http://www.unicef.org/mena/MENA-KAP_Survey_Key_Findings_HCWA_UNICEF_Final.pdf]. {{Legend|#FF0000|55–65%}} {{Legend|#0000FF|15–25%}} {{Legend|#00FF00|Less than 3%}}]]
Female genital mutilation is prevalent in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], with an FGM rate of 72% according to the 2010 WADI report<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stopfgmmideast.org/countries/iraq/ |title=» Iraq |publisher=Stopfgmmideast.org |date= |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref> for the entire region and exceeding 80% in Garmyan and New Kirkuk. In Arbil Governorate and Suleymaniya Type I FGM is common; while in Garmyan and New Kirkuk, Type II and III FGM are common.<ref>[http://www.stopfgmkurdistan.org/study_fgm_iraqi_kurdistan_en.pdf "Female Genital Mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan – A Study"], WADI, accessed 15 February 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Burki T | year = 2010 | title = Reports focus on female genital mutilation in Iraqi Kurdistan | url = | journal = The Lancet | volume = 375 | issue = 9717| page = 794 | doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(10)60330-3}}</ref> There was no law against FGM in Iraqi Kurdistan, but in 2007 a draft legislation condemning the practice was submitted to the Regional Parliament, but was not passed.<ref name="stopfgmkurdistan.org">[http://www.stopfgmkurdistan.org/html/english/updates/update001e.htm "Draft for a Law Prohibiting Female Genital Mutilation is submitted to the Kurdish Regional Parliament"], Stop FGM in Kurdistan, accessed 21 November 2010.</ref> A 2011 Kurdish law criminalized FGM practice in Iraqi Kurdistan <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/08/29/iraqi-kurdistan-law-banning-fgm-not-being-enforced |title=Iraqi Kurdistan: Law Banning FGM Not Being Enforced | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date= |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref> and this law is not being enforced.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/08/29/iraqi-kurdistan-law-banning-fgm-not-being-enforced Iraqi Kurdistan: Law Banning FGM Not Being Enforced] Human Rights Watch, August 29, 2012</ref>
A field report by Iraqi group PANA Center, published in 2012, shows 38% of females in Kirkuk and its surrounding districts areas had undergone female circumcision. Of those females circumcised, 65% were Kurds, 26% Arabs and rest Turkmen. On the level of religious and sectarian affiliation, 41% were Sunnis, 23% Shiites, rest Kaka’is, and none Christians or Chaldeans.<ref>[http://pukmedia.com/EN/EN_Direje.aspx?Jimare=1890 Memorandum to prevent female genital mutilation in Iraq] PUK, Kurdistan (May 2, 2013)</ref> A 2013 report finds FGM prevalence rate of 59% based on clinical examination of about 2000 Iraqi Kurdish women; FGM found were Type I, and 60% of the mutilation were performed to girls in 4–7 year age group.<ref>Yasin et al. (September 2013) {{cite journal | doi = 10.1186/1471-2458-13-809 | volume=13 | title=Female genital mutilation among Iraqi Kurdish women: a cross-sectional study from Erbil city | year=2013 | journal=BMC Public Health | page=809 | author=Yasin Berivan A}}</ref> See [[Asuda]], a Kurdistan NGO. The highest prevalence rates of FGM are in Kirkuk (20%), Sulaymaniyah (54%) and Erbil (58%).
===Jordan=== Residents of [[Arabah|Wadi Araba]] village in southern [[Jordan]] are known to practice FGM. The practice is foreign to the rest of the country, experts speculate that this practise was introduced through descendants of tribes that came from neighbouring [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] and [[Beer Sheba]].<ref>[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Culture/Arts/Nov/13/The-Jordanian-town-that-still-circumcises-women.ashx#axzz2g5h5CT28 The Jordanian town that still circumcises women] Rana Sabbagh-Gargour, The Star (Lebanon)</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ethics/femalecircumcision/femalecirc_1.shtml Female circumcision/genital cutting] BBC Guide, United Kingdom (2008)</ref>
===Kuwait=== Female genital mutilation is not practiced in Kuwait.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://data.unicef.org/resources/zero-tolerance-female-genital-mutilation |title=Zero Tolerance For Female Genital Mutilation|publisher=unicef.org|date=|accessdate=2018-02-10}}</ref> Few ethnic migrant minorities are believed to perform the procedure outside of public health institutions where they risk injury and infections.
===Oman=== The practice is very prevalent in [[Oman]].<ref name="meforum1">[http://www.meforum.org/1629/is-female-genital-mutilation-an-islamic-problem "Is Female Genital Mutilation an Islamic Problem?"], ''Middle East Quarterly'', accessed 5 February 2011.</ref> A 2013 article by journalist Susan Mubarak describes FGM practice in Oman, and claims the practice is very common in [[Dhofar Governorate|Dhofar]] in the southwest. The author went on to say that a previous article on the topic received both positive feedback for spreading awareness of what some considered a 'horrific tradition', as well as negative feedback from others for 'hanging Dhofar’s dirty washing for the world to see and criticising a practice that they believe is purely Islamic,' commenting that she 'paid little attention to these criticisms because I know the practice is harmful and primitive', and 'our religion neither encourages the practice nor condemns it.'<ref name="muscatdaily.com"/>
According to a small survey by human rights activist and statistician Habiba Al Hinai conducted in October 2013 and published in January 2014, 78% of 100 women interviewed living in the capital city of [[Muscat]] had undergone FGM. These women came from all parts of the country, each region showing a very high prevalence, and even though fewer women from Muscat itself had undergone FGM, they were still in the majority. Her findings contradicted the common belief that FGM was only widespread in the south.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wluml.org/news/new-study-oman-shows-high-prevalence-fgm-all-over-country |title=New study in Oman shows high prevalence of FGM all over the country | Women Reclaiming and Redefining Cultures |publisher=Wluml.org |date=22 January 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref> Type I is mostly performed in southern Oman and typically performed within a few weeks of a girl's birth, while Type IV is observed in other parts of northern Oman.<ref>[http://www.theweek.co.om/printCon.aspx?Cval=6181 FOCUS ON FGM] Victoria Cuthbert, The Week (Oman), (April 25, 2012)</ref>
FGM otherwise is not practice in Oman neither is considered prominent by the World Health Organization.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
===Palestine=== {{Expand section|date=November 2014}} Female genital mutilation is present in [[State of Palestine|Palestine]].<ref name="unfpa1"/>
===Qatar=== {{Expand section|date=November 2014}} Female genital mutilation is present in [[Qatar]].<ref name="gulfnews.com">[http://gulfnews.com/opinions/columnists/female-genital-mutilation-a-brutal-violation-of-rights-1.1036052 Female genital mutilation: a brutal violation of rights] Asma Malik, Gulf News (June 15, 2012)</ref><ref name="irinnews.org"/>
===Saudi Arabia=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name=Birch/><ref name="fgmnetwork.org"/> FGM is most prevalent in Saudi regions following [[Shafi'i]] school within the Sunni sect of Islam, such as [[Hejaz]], Tihamah and Asir.<ref>Berg, R. C., Denison, E., & Fretheim, A. (2010). Psychological, social and sexual consequences of female genital. Report from Kunnskapssenteret, (13), Norway</ref><ref>[http://2001-2009.state.gov/g/wi/rls/rep/9276.htm FGM Prevalence] US Department of State (2001)</ref><ref>Al-Sharabasi, Ahmad (1980), Yas'alunak fi al-din wal-hayat, 4th Edition, II, pp 31; also see I:253-255</ref> In a clinical study, Alsibiani and Rouzi provide evidence of the practice in Saudi Arabia.<ref>Alsibiani, S. A., & Rouzi, A. A. (2010). Sexual function in women with female genital mutilation. Fertility and sterility, 93(3), 722-724</ref> Another 2010 report claims post-FGM medical complications are an indicator of widespread prevalence of the practice in Saudi women.<ref>Rouzi, A. A. (2010). Epidermal clitoral inclusion cysts: not a rare complication of female genital mutilation. Human reproduction, 25(7), 1672-1674</ref> A 2012 study finds, that of the Saudi women who had FGM, Type III was more common than Type I or II.<ref>Berg, R. C., & Denison, E. (2012). Does female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) affect women’s sexual functioning? A systematic review of the sexual consequences of FGM/C. Sexuality research and social policy, 9(1), 41-56</ref>
===Syria=== Circumstantial evidence suggests FGM exists in [[Syria]].<ref name=Birch/><ref name="fgmnetwork.org"/> A 2012 conference confirmed that FGM is observed in Syria.<ref name="gulfnews.com"/>
===Turkey=== Though there is little hard evidence of the practice of FGM in Turkey, circumstantial evidence suggests FGM exists in the southern Turkey where the majority of the population is Kurdish.<ref name=Birch/><ref>[http://www.khrp.org/khrp-news/human-rights-documents/briefing-papers/doc_download/218-the-practice-of-female-genital-mutilation-fgm-in-the-kurdish-regions.html The Practice of Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) in the Kurdish Regions] Acharya (2009), Kurdish Human Rights Project</ref>
===United Arab Emirates=== The WHO mentions a study that documents FGM in the [[United Arab Emirates]], but does not provide data.<ref name="irinnews.org"/><ref>[http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2008/9789241596442_eng.pdf "Eliminating Female Genital Mutilation: An interagency statement"], World Health Organization, 2008, p. 30.</ref> The practice is reportedly prevalent in rural and urban UAE.<ref name="Kvello_2003">{{Cite conference |first = Ane |last = Kvello |author2=Sayed L |author3=Sundby J |title = Concerning female circumcision in the United Arab Emirates: Is clitoridectomy in a traditional context an assault against women? |booktitle = FOKO 2003 – ABSTRACTS |publisher = University of Oslo |date = 2003-09-06 |url = http://www.med.uio.no/iasam/inthel/foko/invitation.html}}</ref>) In a 2011 survey, 34% of Emirati female respondents said FGM had been performed on them, and explained the practice to customs and tradition.<ref name=tnuae11>[http://www.thenational.ae/lifestyle/fatal-traditions-female-circumcision-in-the-uae#full Fatal traditions: Female circumcision in the UAE] Wafa Al Marzouqi (Jul 23, 2011), The National, United Arab Emirates</ref> FGM is a controversial topic in UAE, and people argue about whether it is an Islamic requirement or a tribal tradition. A significant number of UAE nationals follow in the footsteps of their parents and grandparents without questioning the practice. A 2012 report published by UAE government scores UAE at 31% on prevalence of Female Genital Mutilation.<ref>[http://www.dwe.gov.ae/data2/Book_I.pdf UAE Women Index Report 2012] Shamsa Saleh, UAE (2012)</ref>
===Yemen=== According to a 2008 UNICEF report, 30% prevalence;<ref name="applications.emro.who.int"/> in addition to the adult prevalence, UNICEF reports that 20% of women aged 15–49 have a daughter who had the procedure in [[Yemen]].<ref name="fgmnetwork.org"/><ref name="irinnews.org"/><ref>[http://www2.unicef.org/infobycountry/yemen_statistics.html At a glance: Yemen – Statistics], UNICEF, accessed 5 February 2011.</ref> In 4 of Yemen's 21 governorates, according to a 2008 report, the FGM prevalence rates exceed 80%: [[Al Hudaydah Governorate|al-Hudaydah]] (97%), [[Hadhramaut Governorate|Hadhramaut]] (97%), [[Al Mahrah Governorate|al-Mahrah]] (97%) and [['Adan Governorate|Adan]] (82%); [[Sana'a Governorate]], which includes the capital of Yemen, has a prevalence rate of 46%.<ref name="YEMEN 2008">[http://www.irinnews.org/report/79025/yemen-government-body-moves-to-stem-female-genital-mutilation YEMEN: Government body moves to stem female genital mutilation] IRIN, A news service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (2008)</ref> Type II FGM was most common, accounting for 83% of all FGMs. Type I FGMs accounted for 13%.<ref name="YEMEN 2008"/>
Yemeni tradition is to carry out the FGM on a new born, with 97% of FGM being done within the first month of a baby girl. In 2001, Yemen banned FGM in all private and public medical facilities by a government decree, but not homes. The Yemeni government did not enforce this decree. In 2009, conservative Yemeni parliamentarians opposed the adoption of a nationwide criminal law against FGM.<ref>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-jemen-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Yemen] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> In 2010, the Ministry of Human Rights of Yemen launched a new study to ascertain over 4 years if FGM is being practiced in Yemen, then propose a new law against FGM.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report/88058/yemen-new-fgm-c-law-possible-within-four-years-minister YEMEN: New FGM/C law possible "within four years" - minister] IRIN, A news service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (2010)</ref> A 2013 UNICEF report claims Yemen's FGM prevalence rate have not changed in last 30 years.<ref>[http://www.unicef.org/esaro/5440_13066.html Overwhelming opposition to female genital mutilation/cutting, yet millions of girls still at risk] UNICEF (July 2013)</ref>
==North America==
===Canada=== There is some evidence to indicate that FGM is practised in Ontario and across Canada among immigrant and refugee communities.<ref>{{cite web|title=FGM in Canada|url=http://www.ohrc.on.ca/en/policy-female-genital-mutilation-fgm/4-fgm-canada|website=Ontario Human Right Commission|publisher=Ontario Human Right Commission|accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref> FGM is considered child assault and prohibited under sections 267 ([[assault causing bodily harm]]) or 268 ([[aggravated assault]], including wounding, maiming, disfiguring) of the [[Criminal Code (Canada)|Criminal Code]].<ref>{{citation|title=Female genital mutilation and health care – an exploration of the needs and roles of affected communities and health care providers in Canada|author=Federal Interdepartmental Working Group on Female Genital Mutilation|publisher=Health Canada|year=1999}} *[http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/ShowDoc/cs/C-46/bo-ga:l_VIII Canada's Criminal Code ( R.S., 1985, c. C-46 )]</ref>
===United States=== {{main|Female genital mutilation in the United States}} The [[Centers for Disease Control]] estimated in 1997 that 168,000 girls living in the United States had undergone FGM or were at risk.<ref name=DuPont1998p85>Cullen-DuPont, Kathryn. "Female genital mutilation,"''Encyclopedia of Women's History in America''. Da Capo Press, 1998, [https://books.google.com/books?id=oIro7MtiFuYC&pg=PA85 p. 85].</ref> [[Khalid Adem]], a Muslim who had moved from Ethiopia to Atlanta, Georgia, became the first person to be convicted in the US in an FGM case; he was sentenced to ten years in 2006 for having severed his two-year-old daughter's clitoris with a pair of scissors.<ref>[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2006-11-01-georgia_x.htm "Man gets 10-year sentence for circumcision of 2-year-old daughter"], Associated Press, 1 November 2006.</ref> Performing the procedure on anyone under the age of 18 became illegal in the U.S. in 1997 with the ''Federal Prohibition of Female Genital Mutilation Act''.<ref>Zabus 2004, p. 110.</ref>
As of 2018, 27 [[U.S. state]]s have specific laws against FGM.<ref>https://www.theahafoundation.org/female-genital-mutilation/</ref> States that do not have such laws may use other general statutes, such as assault, battery or [[child abuse]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theahafoundation.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/FGMLAWS_2013011.pdf |title=Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) Statutes in the United States & United Kingdom| accessdate=March 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515174555/http://theahafoundation.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/FGMLAWS_2013011.pdf |archivedate=May 15, 2013 }}</ref> The ''Transport for Female Genital Mutilation Act'' was passed in January 2013, and prohibits knowingly transporting a girl out of the U.S. for the purpose of undergoing FGM.<ref>Hassan, Yasmeen. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/yasmeen-hassan/new-wins-speed-gains_b_2403941.html "As Global Consensus Accelerates, Obama Strengthens Federal Law Protecting Girls in the Fight Against Female Genital Mutilation"],''The Huffington Post'', 3 January 2013.</ref>
[[Matter of Kasinga|Fauziya Kasinga]], a 19-year-old member of the [[Tchamba]]-Kunsuntu tribe of Togo, was granted asylum in 1996 after leaving an [[arranged marriage]] to escape FGM; this set a precedent in US immigration law because it was the first time FGM was accepted as a form of persecution.<ref>Dugger, Celia W. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05E1DB1439F935A25755C0A960958260 "June 9-15; Asylum From Mutilation"],''The New York Times'', 16 June 1996. *[http://www.justice.gov/eoir/efoia/kasinga7.pdf "In re Fauziya KASINGA, file A73 476 695], U.S. Department of Justice, Executive Office for Immigration Review, decided 13 June 1996. *Dugger, Celia W. [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/nyregion/woman-s-plea-for-asylum-puts-tribal-ritual-on-trial.html "Woman's Plea for Asylum Puts Tribal Ritual on Trial"], ''The New York Times'', 15 April 1996.</ref>
In 2016, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)]] released a report compiled with data from 2010-2013. The 2013 study estimated 513,000 girls and women in the United States were either victims of FGM or at risk of FGM, with ⅓ under age 18.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prb.org/Publications/Articles/2015/us-fgmc.aspx|title=Women and Girls at Risk of Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting in the United States|website=www.prb.org|access-date=2017-10-20}}</ref> The marked increase in the number of girls and women at risk of FGM in the United States was attributed to an increase in the total number of immigrants from countries where FGM is most common, not an increase in the frequency of the practice.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Goldberg|first=Howard|last2=Stupp|first2=Paul|last3=Okoroh|first3=Ekwutosi|last4=Besera|first4=Ghenet|last5=Goodman|first5=David|last6=Danel|first6=Isabella|date=2016|title=Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting in the United States: Updated Estimates of Women and Girls at Risk, 2012|journal=Public Health Reports|volume=131|issue=2|pages=340–347|doi=10.1177/003335491613100218|issn=0033-3549|pmc=4765983|pmid=26957669}}</ref>
==South America==
===Colombia=== The only indigenous tribe in Latin America known to practise FGM is Colombia's [[Emberá people]]. The tradition was extremely secretive and taboo until a 2007 incident, in which a girl died as a result of FGM. The incident caused much controversy, raised awareness and stimulated debate about ending the practice altogether.
